<!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

If you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).

If this may be security issue, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/.
-->

**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:

> Uncomment only one, leave it on its own line:
>
/kind bug
> /kind feature


**What happened**:
I created a job with parallelism=2, 1 container in each pod, and a rbd volume attached to the container.  Attachment was read-only.
Only 1 pod got the RBD mounted while the other POD failed with "still in use" in syslog, referencing the code in rbd_util.go that checks watchers.  Note that this is not the same thing as this:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/63424

which refers to persistent volumes.  This is not a persistent volume -the use case is to map read-only data to multiple containers from a single RBD, like for using a reference data set, etc.  According to the documentation this *should* work (see below).

**What you expected to happen**:

I expect this to happen per the documentation: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#rbd

"A feature of RBD is that it can be mounted as read-only by multiple consumers simultaneously. This means that you can pre-populate a volume with your dataset and then serve it in parallel from as many Pods as you need. Unfortunately, RBD volumes can only be mounted by a single consumer in read-write mode - no simultaneous writers allowed."

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

Create 2 pods, each with 1 container mapping a single rbd read only.

**Anything else we need to know?**:

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):
1.9.4
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration:
self, x86_64 systems
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Ubuntu Xenial
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`):
Linux dal1util6p30 4.4.0-116-generic #140-Ubuntu SMP Mon Feb 12 21:23:04 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
- Install tools:
ceph
- Others:
I believe that in the case where a read-only mapping is being requested, the code should not check watchers.  Again this is consistent with the documentation but it doesn't work that way.  If a PV/PVC is the "right" way to do this it seems seriously overkill and the management overhead is severe, especially in a large scale environment.  The documentation states that the advantage of RBD is to be able to attach read-only volumes to multiple containers concurrently, and this is how I believe it should work.  The watcher check is artificial and really needs to apply only to read/write.  I can fix this bug myself but would like to understand the reasoning behind it a bit more.
Thanks!
Leo Reiter

title: RBD volumes cannot be mapped read only to more than 1 container - not PV related
